Award.AwardTitle: TUES: The Impact of the National Science Foundation on Undergraduate Education - Symposia Highlighting Curricular Innovations.

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
In order to provide NSF-supported innovators in undergraduate STEM curriculum development with an opportunities to disseminate their materials and outcomes, principal investigators (PIs) of projects organize and convene symposia at the Annual National Meeting of the American Chemical Society (ACS) in the Spring of 2015, 2016, and 2017 and at three regional ACS meetings or at the Biennial Conference on Chemical Education during those same years. At the symposia attendees are informed about a variety of NSF programs that promote undergraduate education. The NSF has a tradition of supporting this symposium and surveys have shown that in the past they have been well-attended. During these meetings prospective PIs and practitioners are empowered to ask questions and have awardees address their concerns in-person. Evidence suggests that these interactions are responsible for propagating evidence-based curricular changes at other institutions.

At the National Meetings, the symposia are comprised of two half-day sessions. In the first session, the audience will hear from PIs who have been successfully funded from a variety of NSF programs that focus on STEM undergraduate education. The second session focuses on a theme that has emerging national impact and significance and for which an evidence base is growing. Topics include (a) virtual laboratories, (b) online instruction, (c) research-based upper-level chemistry laboratories, (d) integration of advanced instrumentation into the curriculum, (e) non-traditional topics relating to chemistry across the curriculum, and others. Symposia at ACS regional meetings and the BCCE also involve the dissemination of project results as well as information about NSF Programs. These abbreviated half-day sessions serve to provide information to faculty who might find the expense of attending a national meeting to be a challenge. Evaluation of each meeting is expected to reveal that attendees plan to adapt curricular innovations, have a better understanding of current evidence-based educational techniques, and have greater awareness of NSF funding opportunities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Symposia were organized and held at five Spring ACS National Meetings (Denver, CO in 2015; San Diego, CA in 2016; San Francisco, CA in 2017; New Orleans, LA in 2018; Orlando, FL in 2019), two ACS Regional Meetings (Midwest Regional, St. Joseph, MO in 2015; Northwest Regional, Oregon State University in 2017), and the Biennial Conference on Chemical Education (University of Notre Dame in 2018).  Symposia at the national meetings were two half-day sessions and one half-day sessions were convened at the regional meetings and BCCE.

Symposia at the meetings listed above included approximately 90 presentations describing a wide variety of awards.  Projects funded through MRI, ATE, EPSCoR Research Infrastructure Improvement Program, TUES-Type 1, TUES-Type 2, CCLI-Type 2, NOYCE, S-STEM, and IUSE programs were presented at the national meetings.  The regional meetings included projects funded by the ATE, WIDER, TUES, NOYCE, S-STEM, and IUSE programs.  The BCCE symposium included projects funded by the ATE, IUSE, S-STEM, and NOYCE programs of the National Science Foundation.  Program Officers of NSF provided an overview of programs and relevant information to audiences at the national meetings and BCCE.  A question and answer session followed, allowing for individuals to directly interact with the NSF personnel.  A former Program Officer (Rotator) and co-organizer of the symposium gave an overview of NSF programs at the regional meetings.  Overall, a wide spectrum of educational projects were described, reiterating the significant impact that the NSF has on chemical education. 

This project had three primary objectives.  The first was to have a venue and opportunity available for NSF award winners to disseminate the outcomes of their projects to an interested audience of educators.  The second was to inform attendees of funding opportunities available through NSF and changes within certain programs.  Finally, this project was to allow for anecdotal evaluation of one chosen program within the NSF by focusing on student learning through curricular changes and innovations made possible by projects funded by that program.

Regarding the first objective, eight total symposia (national and regional) were organized and convened to provide NSF award winners a venue at which to disseminate their projects.  The presentations were varied and described information about planning for the original proposal, obtaining buy-in from colleagues, getting established after receiving the award, the actual project itself, and assessment.  Many presenters continued to have conversations and exchanged contact information with interested colleagues during intermissions.  Almost 90 presentations were given by educators from universities, colleges, community colleges, and private educational institutions.  Overall, attendance was very good compared to other symposium within the CHED Division of ACS as confirmed by Program Chairs. 

The second objective of informing educators and administrators as to the funding opportunities available through NSF was met at each of the eight symposia.  Each of the symposia at national meetings and BCCE included a dedicated time for an NSF Program Officer to discuss programs and any NSF related changes relevant to chemical education and STEM in general.  A former Program Officer provided a similar overview during the symposia at the regional meetings.  Beneficial exchanges were made between the Officers and audience as the question/answer periods always ran to the time limit. 

Regarding placing attention on a specific program supported by NSF, this was accomplished at each of the national meetings.  An entire half-day session was organized to include presenters with projects supported by the same program.  Because of this goal, speakers were personally invited after the co-organizers reviewed funded projects.  Because of the distribution of relevant funded projects, the S-STEM program was featured at four and the IUSE program at one of the symposia.  Diversity was maintained at BCCE and the regional meetings.  Feedback from the presenters, indicated that the goals of the S-STEM program are being met.  These presentations covered aspects of the program such as recruitment, retention, and transfer issues.  Many focused on assisting low income and academically talented students to assure them assess to higher education and a career in STEM.  All presentations focused on student success.  Many also described collaborations/partnerships that were established between areas within a department, between departments, between institutions, and between institutions and industry.  Substantial ideas and information was exchanged.

The impact on the discipline of chemistry will be determined by those audience members who returned to their institutions and incorporated ideas learned from attending the respective meeting.  This may have been in the form of knowledge, new experiments, modified or different teaching pedagogy, recruitment and retention strategies, scholarship program development, or some other modification to their existing program.  Audience members may have also submitted a proposal to NSF to obtain funding for funding of these educational initiatives.  This impact would sustain years past the Symposia.
